awd_titl_txt: IUCRC Phase I: The University of Michigan Center for High Pressure Plasma Energy, Agriculture, and Biomedical Technologies (PEAB)
awd_abstract_narration:
Advances in atmospheric pressure plasma science have enabled breakthrough opportunities to improve our Nation?s healthcare, economic prosperity and defense.  These science breakthroughs have resulted in the development of new technologies in green energy, environmental remediation, water treatment, medicine, food processing, and agriculture. These are the core fundamental areas of science and technology to be addressed by the Center for High Pressure Plasma Energy, Agriculture, and Biomedical Technologies (C-PEAB). Drexel University (DU), University of Michigan (UM), and George Washington University (GWU), leading institutions in the scientific subject area, are synergistically collaborating with each other and with their industrial partners as the founding members of the C-PEAB.  This effort will support STEM education with focused recruitment of women and underrepresented minorities, produce an interdisciplinary workforce, and integrate novel breakthrough technologies with industry. While having long-term collaborations in plasma science with GWU and DU, UM's unique contribution to the C-PEAB team is based upon pioneering research in plasma modeling of atmospheric pressure plasmas and plasma-based water purification. UM has extensive experience in the study of plasma decomposition of contaminants in water as well as engineering the scale up of plasma reactors to treat volumes of practical interest to the consumer and industrial sector. 

Low Temperature non-equilibrium Plasma (LTP) science is the base upon which many modern industries such as microelectronics and micro-fabrication have been built. Current breakthroughs in plasma-generating electronics have made it possible to widen the area of LTP applications to atmos-pheric and higher pressures. These application areas are the focus of the Center for High Pressure Plasma Energy, Agriculture, and Biomedical Technologies (C-PEAB). The C-PEAB will translate science breakthroughs in diagnostics, pulse power and modeling to optimizing industrial applications in energy, environmental remediation, food safety and food processing, and medical and bioengi-neering. C-PEAB will initially consist of a three-site IUCRC between Drexel University (DU), University of Michigan (UM), and George Washington University (GWU) with subsequent addition of new member universities who have strong industry collaborations in high-pressure plasma applications pertinent to the C-PEAB.  While having long-term collaboration experience in plasma science with GWU and DU, the University of Michigan's unique contribution to the C-PEAB team is especially based upon the University's core expertise in the science and engineering of atmospheric plasmas in contact with liquids including: 1) advanced computational simulation tools and 2) high throughput plasma reactors for the purpose of advanced water treatment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The UM contribution to the IUCRC involved the study and application of plasmas interacting with water for the purpose of removal of contaminants such as PFAS in water as well as the activation of regular tap water with long lived reactive species for the purpose of creating a disinfecting, nontoxic washwater for cleaning fruits and vegatables. In this respect, the overaching goal is to used plasma to remove toxic contaminants from drinking water as well as prevent food borne illness though the use of plasma activated water.  An additional task aimed to better understand metal plasmas supporting the production of isotopes.  Such isotopes are important for medical diagnostics. 

In general, plasmas have demonstrated the capacity to disinfect water and produced activated water for disinfection. The problem with plasmas operating in regular air is that the sized of the plasma and thus its attachment "footprint" on the surface of the water is small. This is due to the fact that electron drift distance in air is only a microwater so plasmas cannot spread out.  The effort involved optimizing plasma liquid water contact surace area to improve the rate of injection of plasma generated species into the water. This effort allowed for commissioning a reactor devloped on a previous NSF to the problems of interest to the member companies. The reactor was used to remove PFAS compunds from actual contaminated groundwater to levels below the maximum concentration levels as required by the State of Michigan. A secondary goal of this effort was to remove hydrocarbons in emulsions of  water and oil generated by the food processing industry. Through the removal of the oil, the water could be reused. In another effort, the objective was to use plasma to control the pH of the water with applications ranging from fruit and vegetable cleaning to drinking water on-demand with user defined pH. This latter project required exploiting plasma's ability to produce acidic and basic species. By balancing these processes, pH could be varied. The experiment showed great promise in preventing the decay of strawberries. The metal plasma study resulted in an experimenal undertanding of electron beam physics  as well as a tabulation of important cross section data used to model metal plasmals. Overall these efforts contributed to the production of 2 phd and the training of three undergrads as well as number of additional graduate students. The activity introduced the students to technological startups and the importance of such companies.


Last Modified: 12/27/2023
Modified by: John E Foster

The UM contribution to the IUCRC involved the study and application of plasmas interacting with water for the purpose of removal of contaminants such as PFAS in water as well as the activation of regular tap water with long lived reactive species for the purpose of creating a disinfecting, nontoxic washwater for cleaning fruits and vegatables. In this respect, the overaching goal is to used plasma to remove toxic contaminants from drinking water as well as prevent food borne illness though the use of plasma activated water. An additional task aimed to better understand metal plasmas supporting the production of isotopes. Such isotopes are important for medical diagnostics.


In general, plasmas have demonstrated the capacity to disinfect water and produced activated water for disinfection. The problem with plasmas operating in regular air is that the sized of the plasma and thus its attachment "footprint" on the surface of the water is small. This is due to the fact that electron drift distance in air is only a microwater so plasmas cannot spread out. The experiment showed great promise in preventing the decay of strawberries. The metal plasma study resulted in an experimenal undertanding of electron beam physics as well as a tabulation of important cross section data used to model metal plasmals. Overall these efforts contributed to the production of 2 phd and the training of three undergrads as well as number of additional graduate students.
